levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying the value of each digit in a four-digit number using Dienes blocks (thousands cube, hundreds flat, tens rod, ones cube) on a place value mat.
levels.example_task: Build 2,365 with Dienes blocks on the place value mat. How many thousands, hundreds, tens and ones?
levels.example_response: 2 thousands, 3 hundreds, 6 tens, 5 ones. The 2 is worth 2000, the 3 is worth 300, the 6 is worth 60, the 5 is worth 5.
common_errors: Saying the 2 is worth 2 rather than 2000
Confusing the thousands cube with the hundreds flat when building the number

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Partitioning four-digit numbers into standard form (Th + H + T + O) using arrow cards, including numbers with zero placeholders.
levels.example_task: Partition 4,073 into thousands, hundreds, tens and ones. What does the 0 mean?
levels.example_response: 4,073 = 4000 + 0 + 70 + 3. The 0 means there are no hundreds.
common_errors: Writing 4,073 as 473 (omitting the zero placeholder)
Saying the 0 has no meaning rather than explaining it represents zero hundreds

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Stating the value of any digit in any four-digit number instantly, comparing and ordering four-digit numbers, and partitioning flexibly.
levels.example_task: What is the value of the 8 in 5,831? Order these: 3,456; 3,465; 3,546; 3,564.
common_errors: Saying the 8 is worth 80 (reading it as the tens digit)
Ordering by looking only at the last digit rather than comparing column by column from the left

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining how the place value system works multiplicatively — each column is 10 times the column to its right — and using this to reason about numbers up to 10,000.
levels.example_task: Why is 3,000 the same as 300 tens? Explain using place value.
levels.example_response: 3,000 = 3 × 1000. Since 1000 = 100 × 10, that means 3,000 = 300 × 10 = 300 tens. Each column is worth 10 times the column to its right.
common_errors: Knowing the answer but unable to explain the multiplicative relationship between columns
Confusing 300 tens with 30 tens

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 25s from 0 to 200 using 25p coins as concrete support.
levels.example_task: Place 25p coins in a line. Count the total: 25, 50, 75... Continue to 200.
common_errors: Stumbling at 75 to 100 (saying 80 instead of 100)
Losing the pattern after 100 (e.g. saying 100, 200 instead of 100, 125)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting in 6s, 7s and 9s from 0, using a hundred square or known facts as support.
levels.example_task: Count in 7s from 0 to 70.
common_errors: Errors in the middle of the sequence (saying 42, 48 instead of 42, 49)
Adding 6 instead of 7 (confusing the 6 and 7 times table sequences)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting fluently in 6s, 7s, 9s, 25s and 1000s from any starting multiple, forwards and backwards.
levels.example_task: Start at 36. Count in 9s to 72. Count in 1000s from 3000 to 9000.
common_errors: Needing to start from 0 to reach the given starting number
Counting backwards in 9s: errors at transitions (72, 62 instead of 72, 63)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading temperatures below zero on a large vertical number line (thermometer) and counting through zero.
levels.example_task: The temperature is 3°C. It drops by 5 degrees. Use the thermometer to count back. What is the new temperature?
levels.example_response: 3, 2, 1, 0, –1, –2. The new temperature is –2°C.
common_errors: Stopping at 0 and saying the answer is 0°C
Counting 3, 2, 1, 0, 1, 2 instead of going into negative numbers

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Ordering negative numbers and comparing them, including recognising that –7 is less than –3.
levels.example_task: Which is colder, –3°C or –7°C? Put these in order from coldest to warmest: 5°C, –2°C, 0°C, –6°C.
levels.example_response: –7°C is colder. Order: –6°C, –2°C, 0°C, 5°C.
common_errors: Saying –3°C is colder because 3 < 7 (comparing absolute values)
Placing 0°C before the negative numbers in the order

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Calculating intervals that cross zero and using negative numbers in real-world contexts without a number line.
levels.example_task: The temperature at midnight was –4°C. By midday it was 9°C. What was the temperature rise?
levels.example_response: From –4 to 0 is 4 degrees, from 0 to 9 is 9 degrees. Total rise = 4 + 9 = 13 degrees.
common_errors: Computing 9 – 4 = 5 (not accounting for the crossing of zero)
Computing 9 + 4 = 13 correctly but unable to explain why you add

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving multi-step problems involving negative numbers and explaining the reasoning.
levels.example_task: The temperature was –3°C. It rose by 8 degrees, then dropped by 12 degrees. What is the final temperature?
levels.example_response: –3 + 8 = 5°C. Then 5 – 12 = –7°C. The final temperature is –7°C.
common_errors: Losing track of the sign at intermediate steps
Computing 5 – 12 as 7 instead of –7

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Rounding two-digit numbers to the nearest 10 using a number line showing the two bounding multiples.
levels.example_task: Round 47 to the nearest 10. Is it closer to 40 or 50?
levels.example_response: 47 rounds to 50 because 47 is closer to 50 than to 40 (it is only 3 away from 50 but 7 away from 40).
common_errors: Rounding 47 down to 40 (always rounding down)
Not knowing the rule for 5: 45 rounds up to 50

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Rounding three-digit numbers to the nearest 10 and 100, using the 'look at the next digit' rule.
levels.example_task: Round 463 to the nearest 10. Round 463 to the nearest 100.
levels.example_response: To nearest 10: 460 (the ones digit 3 is less than 5). To nearest 100: 500 (the tens digit 6 is 5 or more).
common_errors: Looking at the wrong digit: rounding to nearest 100 but checking the ones digit
Rounding 463 to the nearest 100 as 400 (looking at the wrong digit)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Rounding any number to the nearest 10, 100 or 1000, and using rounding to estimate answers to calculations.
levels.example_task: Round 7,549 to the nearest 1000. Estimate 3,782 + 5,109 by rounding each to the nearest 1000.
common_errors: Rounding 7,549 to the nearest 1000 by looking at the tens digit (giving 7,500 instead of 8,000)
Forgetting to round both numbers when estimating

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading and writing Roman numerals I to X and matching them to Hindu-Arabic numerals.
levels.example_task: Write these in Roman numerals: 3, 7, 10.
levels.example_response: 3 = III, 7 = VII, 10 = X.
common_errors: Writing 4 as IIII instead of IV
Confusing V (5) and X (10)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and writing Roman numerals using I, V, X, L and C, applying the subtractive rule for 4, 9, 40, 90.
levels.example_task: Write 49 in Roman numerals. What number is XCIV?
levels.example_response: 49 = XLIX. XCIV = 94.
common_errors: Writing 49 as IL (not valid — subtractive rule only works with adjacent values: I before V or X, X before L or C)
Reading IV as 6 (adding instead of subtracting)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Converting any number from 1 to 100 between Roman numerals and Hindu-Arabic, and explaining why the Roman system has no place value.
levels.example_task: Write 87 in Roman numerals. Why did the Roman system need separate symbols for 50 (L) and 100 (C)?
levels.example_response: 87 = LXXXVII. The Roman system has no place value — the position of a digit does not change its value. So they needed different symbols for different amounts: L for 50 and C for 100. Our system uses position instead.
common_errors: Confusing 87 with 78 when converting
Being unable to explain the difference between the place value system and the Roman system

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Completing columnar addition of two four-digit numbers with no exchanges (no carrying).
levels.example_task: Use column addition: 3,214 + 2,563.
levels.example_response:
3214
+  2563
------
   5777
No carrying needed.
common_errors: Misaligning digits (putting thousands under hundreds)
Adding from left to right rather than right to left

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Completing columnar addition and subtraction with exchanges (carrying/borrowing) in one or two columns.
levels.example_task: Use column subtraction: 5,432 – 2,876.
levels.example_response: 5432 – 2876 = 2556. Borrowing needed in the ones (12 – 6 = 6), tens (2 – 7 requires borrow: 12 – 7 = 5), and hundreds (3 – 8 requires borrow: 13 – 8 = 5).
common_errors: Forgetting to reduce the next column after borrowing
Subtracting the smaller digit from the larger regardless of position (e.g. 2 – 6 = 4 in the ones column)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reliably computing any four-digit addition or subtraction using formal columnar methods, with estimation to check.
levels.example_task: Work out 6,003 – 2,458. Estimate first.
levels.example_response: Estimate: 6,000 – 2,500 = 3,500. Formal: 6003 – 2458 = 3545. Cascading exchange through zeros: borrow from 6 thousands through the hundreds and tens.
common_errors: Cascading exchange through zeros is the hardest case — pupils often get 6,003 – 2,458 wrong because three consecutive exchanges are needed
Not estimating first and therefore not catching large errors

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving multi-step problems requiring addition and subtraction of four-digit numbers and explaining the method.
levels.example_task: A school has 2,456 fiction books and 1,789 non-fiction books. They buy 325 more fiction books and donate 450 non-fiction books. How many books does the school have now?
common_errors: Mixing up which operation to use for buying (add) vs donating (subtract)
Carrying errors across multiple sequential calculations

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recalling multiplication facts for the 6 and 9 times tables using known facts (e.g. 6 = 2 × 3, 9 = 10 – 1 strategy).
levels.example_task: What is 6 × 4? Use a fact you already know to help.
common_errors: Confusing 6 × 4 with 6 + 4 = 10
Deriving correctly but slowly — not yet at recall speed

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recalling multiplication facts to 12 × 12 with increasing speed, including the hardest facts (6 × 7, 7 × 8, 8 × 9).
levels.example_task: Answer as quickly as you can: 7 × 8 = ? 9 × 6 = ? 12 × 7 = ?
common_errors: Confusing 7 × 8 = 56 with 6 × 8 = 48
Knowing 9 × 6 but not 6 × 9 without recomputing

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Instant recall of all multiplication and related division facts to 12 × 12, applied in calculation and problem-solving.
common_errors: Division facts are less secure than multiplication facts (knowing 8 × 9 = 72 but hesitating on 72 ÷ 8)
Not connecting 770 ÷ 7 = 110 to the known fact 77 ÷ 7 = 11

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Multiplying a two-digit number by a one-digit number using the grid method as pictorial support.
levels.example_task: Use the grid method: 34 × 6.
common_errors: Forgetting to add the partial products
Multiplying 3 × 6 = 18 instead of 30 × 6 = 180 (not partitioning correctly)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Multiplying two-digit and three-digit numbers by one digit using the compact (short multiplication) method with carrying.
levels.example_task: Use short multiplication: 247 × 3.
common_errors: Forgetting to add the carried digit (getting 721 instead of 741)
Writing the carry digit in the wrong column

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reliably completing short multiplication for any 2- or 3-digit × 1-digit calculation, checking with estimation.
levels.example_task: Work out 368 × 7. Estimate first.
levels.example_response: Estimate: 400 × 7 = 2,800. Calculation: 368 × 7 = 2,576. This is close to the estimate, so it looks correct.
common_errors: Multiple carrying errors in sequence (particularly when carries occur in every column)
Not estimating first and therefore missing large errors

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving multi-step word problems that require short multiplication and explaining why the method works using place value.
levels.example_task: A box holds 256 crayons. A school orders 8 boxes. How many crayons in total? Explain how the short multiplication method uses place value.
levels.example_response: 256 × 8 = 2,048. The method works column by column from right: 6 ones × 8 = 48 ones (write 8, carry 4 tens), 5 tens × 8 = 40 tens + 4 = 44 tens (write 4, carry 4 hundreds), 2 hundreds × 8 = 16 hundreds + 4 = 20 hundreds = 2 thousands.
common_errors: Getting the calculation correct but unable to explain the place value reasoning behind the carries
Not writing the answer in context (missing the unit — crayons)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding all factor pairs of a number up to 20 by systematic trial with concrete arrays.
levels.example_task: Find all the ways to arrange 12 counters in equal rows. List the factor pairs of 12.
common_errors: Missing the pair (3,4) and only finding (1,12) and (2,6)
Not knowing when to stop checking (checking 5, 6, 7... when 4 × 3 already found)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding factor pairs of numbers up to 50 systematically and using commutativity to reorder calculations.
levels.example_task: List all factor pairs of 36. Use commutativity to work out 4 × 13 × 25 efficiently.
common_errors: Missing (4,9) or (3,12) when listing factor pairs of 36
Not spotting that 4 × 25 = 100 makes the calculation easier

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding all factor pairs of numbers up to 100, distinguishing factors from multiples, and using factor pairs in mental calculation.
levels.example_task: Is 7 a factor of 42? Is 42 a multiple of 7? Explain the difference between factors and multiples.
levels.example_response: Yes, 7 is a factor of 42 because 42 ÷ 7 = 6 exactly. Yes, 42 is a multiple of 7 because 7 × 6 = 42. Factors divide the number exactly; multiples are the products of multiplying.
common_errors: Confusing factors and multiples (saying '42 is a factor of 7')
Listing some factors of 42 as 7, 14, 21 (listing multiples of 7 instead of factors of 42)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Shading hundredths on a 10×10 grid and writing the decimal as 0.01 per square, using the grid as concrete support.
levels.example_task: Shade 23 squares on the hundredths grid. Write this as a decimal.
levels.example_response: 0.23. Twenty-three hundredths.
common_errors: Writing 0.023 (confusing hundredths with thousandths)
Miscounting the shaded squares on the grid

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying the value of each digit in a number with two decimal places and understanding that 10 hundredths = 1 tenth.
levels.example_task: What is the value of the 4 in 0.47? How many hundredths make one tenth?
levels.example_response: The 4 is worth 4 tenths (0.4). 10 hundredths make 1 tenth (0.10 = 0.1).
common_errors: Saying the 4 is worth 4 hundredths (confusing its position)
Not understanding that 0.10 = 0.1

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting up and down in hundredths, comparing decimals with different numbers of decimal places, and connecting to fractions.
levels.example_task: Which is larger, 0.7 or 0.65? Explain. Write 0.45 as a fraction.
levels.example_response: 0.7 is larger. 0.7 = 0.70, and 70 hundredths > 65 hundredths. 0.45 = 45/100 = 9/20.
common_errors: Saying 0.65 > 0.7 because 65 > 7 (the most critical decimal misconception)
Not knowing how to simplify 45/100 to 9/20

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Generating equivalent fractions by shading fraction walls and comparing the sizes visually.
levels.example_task: Using the fraction wall, find a fraction equivalent to 1/2 with a denominator of 6.
levels.example_response: 3/6. Looking at the fraction wall, 3 sixths takes up the same amount of space as 1 half.
common_errors: Saying 2/6 (adding 1 to numerator and denominator) instead of 3/6
Not understanding why the fraction wall shows equivalence

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Generating families of equivalent fractions using the rule: multiply (or divide) numerator and denominator by the same number.
levels.example_task: Write three fractions equivalent to 2/5.
levels.example_response: 4/10, 6/15, 8/20. I multiplied top and bottom by 2, then 3, then 4.
common_errors: Multiplying only the numerator (writing 4/5, 6/5, 8/5)
Adding the same number instead of multiplying (writing 3/6, 4/7, 5/8)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using equivalent fractions to compare and order fractions with different denominators.
levels.example_task: Which is larger, 3/4 or 5/6? Show your working using a common denominator.
levels.example_response: Common denominator of 4 and 6 is 12. 3/4 = 9/12. 5/6 = 10/12. So 5/6 > 3/4.
common_errors: Comparing numerators without finding a common denominator (saying 5/6 > 3/4 because 5 > 3)
Finding a common denominator but converting the fractions incorrectly

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using money to establish key equivalences: 50p = half of £1, 25p = quarter of £1.
levels.example_task: What fraction of £1 is 50p? What fraction of £1 is 25p? Write them as decimals.
common_errors: Writing 1/2 = 0.2 (confusing the decimal representation)
Not connecting 25p to a quarter of a pound

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Knowing decimal equivalents of tenths and key fractions: 1/2 = 0.5, 1/4 = 0.25, 3/4 = 0.75, 1/10 = 0.1.
levels.example_task: Write 3/4 as a decimal. Write 0.1 as a fraction.
common_errors: Writing 3/4 = 0.34 (reading the digits of the fraction as the decimal)
Writing 1/4 = 0.4 (using the denominator as the decimal digit)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Converting fluently between fraction and decimal forms for all tenths and key fractions, in measurement and money contexts.
levels.example_task: Convert 7/10 to a decimal. A plank is 0.75 m long. What fraction of a metre is that?
common_errors: Knowing 0.75 = 3/4 for money but not recognising it in a measurement context
Not being able to convert any tenth (e.g. 3/10 = 0.3) beyond the memorised facts

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding the area of a rectangle by counting unit squares on squared paper.
levels.example_task: Count the squares inside this 4 × 3 rectangle drawn on squared paper. What is its area?
levels.example_response: 12 squares. The area is 12 cm².
common_errors: Counting the perimeter squares instead of all interior squares
Miscounting by skipping a row

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding the area of a rectangle using length × width, and understanding area is measured in square units.
levels.example_task: A rectangle is 7 cm long and 5 cm wide. What is its area?
levels.example_response: Area = 7 × 5 = 35 cm².
common_errors: Computing the perimeter (7 + 5 + 7 + 5 = 24) instead of the area
Forgetting the unit (writing 35 instead of 35 cm²)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding area of rectilinear shapes by decomposing into rectangles, and clearly distinguishing area from perimeter.
levels.example_task: Find the area of this L-shape by splitting it into two rectangles. The L-shape is 6 cm tall and 4 cm wide at the top, with a 2 cm × 3 cm section removed from the bottom right.
levels.example_response: Split into two rectangles: top rectangle 4 × 4 = 16 cm², bottom rectangle 2 × 2 = 4 cm². Alternatively: full 6 × 4 = 24, minus 2 × 3 = 6: 24 – 6 = 18 cm².
common_errors: Not decomposing the shape correctly and double-counting or missing an area
Computing perimeter when asked for area

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Knowing the key metric conversion facts for length: 1 km = 1000 m, 1 m = 100 cm.
levels.example_task: How many centimetres in 1 metre? How many metres in 1 kilometre?
levels.example_response: 100 cm in 1 m. 1000 m in 1 km.
common_errors: Saying 1 m = 10 cm or 1 km = 100 m (confusing the multipliers)
Not remembering which unit is larger (thinking cm is bigger than m)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Converting between standard metric units in one direction (larger to smaller: multiply) for length, mass and capacity.
levels.example_task: Convert 3 km to metres. Convert 2.5 kg to grams.
common_errors: Dividing instead of multiplying when converting to smaller units
Writing 2.5 kg = 250 g (multiplying by 100 instead of 1000)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Converting in both directions between all common metric units and using these in context.
levels.example_task: A jug holds 1,750 ml. How many litres and millilitres is that? A shelf is 250 cm long. How many metres?
common_errors: Writing 1,750 ml = 17.5 l (dividing by 100 instead of 1000)
Multiplying when they should divide for smaller-to-larger conversion

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading coordinates from a labelled first-quadrant grid where both axes are marked in ones.
levels.example_task: What are the coordinates of point A on this grid? [A is at position (3, 5)]
levels.example_response: (3, 5). Along 3, up 5.
common_errors: Reversing the coordinates: writing (5, 3) instead of (3, 5)
Reading the grid line number instead of the position (counting lines rather than spaces)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Plotting coordinates on a first-quadrant grid and describing positions using coordinate language.
levels.example_task: Plot the point (6, 2) on the grid. Plot the point (2, 6). Are they the same?
levels.example_response: [Plots (6, 2) correctly — 6 along, 2 up. Plots (2, 6) correctly — 2 along, 6 up.] No, they are different points. The order matters.
common_errors: Plotting (6, 2) and (2, 6) at the same point
Not understanding that the first number is horizontal and the second is vertical

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using coordinates to describe positions, plot shapes and describe translations on a first-quadrant grid.
levels.example_task: A rectangle has corners at (1, 1), (1, 4) and (5, 1). What are the coordinates of the fourth corner?
levels.example_response: (5, 4). The fourth corner must complete the rectangle: same x as (5, 1) and same y as (1, 4).
common_errors: Guessing (4, 5) by simply combining the other numbers
Not recognising that opposite corners of a rectangle share x or y coordinates

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Sorting triangles into right-angled, equilateral and isosceles by looking at their side lengths and angles using concrete shape tiles.
levels.example_task: Sort these triangles into three groups: right-angled, equilateral and isosceles.
levels.example_response: [Groups triangles correctly by measuring sides with a ruler and checking for right angles with a set square]
common_errors: Classifying by appearance only (prototypical shapes) rather than by measurement
Not recognising that a triangle can be both right-angled and isosceles

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Classifying quadrilaterals (square, rectangle, parallelogram, rhombus, trapezium) by their properties.
levels.example_task: What properties make a shape a parallelogram? Is a rectangle a parallelogram?
levels.example_response: A parallelogram has two pairs of parallel sides. Yes, a rectangle is a special parallelogram because it also has 2 pairs of parallel sides (plus right angles).
common_errors: Saying rectangles and parallelograms are completely different shapes
Not recognising a tilted square as a square

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Classifying any triangle or quadrilateral from a description or diagram, using precise property-based reasoning.
levels.example_task: A shape has 4 sides, all the same length, but no right angles. What is it? Explain why it is not a square.
levels.example_response: It is a rhombus. A square also has 4 equal sides, but a square must have right angles. A rhombus does not need right angles.
common_errors: Saying it must be a square because all sides are equal
Not knowing the name 'rhombus'

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying a vertical line of symmetry in common shapes using a mirror or by folding.
levels.example_task: Does this shape have a line of symmetry? Use the mirror to check.
levels.example_response: Yes, if I place the mirror down the middle, both halves are the same. It has a vertical line of symmetry.
common_errors: Only checking for vertical symmetry and missing horizontal or diagonal lines
Saying a shape has symmetry when the fold does not match exactly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying all lines of symmetry in regular polygons and completing a symmetric figure given one line of symmetry on squared paper.
levels.example_task: How many lines of symmetry does a regular pentagon have? Complete this shape so it is symmetric about the dotted line.
levels.example_response: A regular pentagon has 5 lines of symmetry. [Completes the shape by reflecting each point the same distance on the other side of the line]
common_errors: Thinking a regular pentagon has only 1 line of symmetry
Reflecting points inaccurately (not counting squares carefully)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying all lines of symmetry in 2-D shapes in any orientation and explaining whether a shape has 0, 1, or multiple lines of symmetry.
levels.example_task: Does this parallelogram (not a rectangle) have any lines of symmetry? Explain.
levels.example_response: No. A parallelogram that is not a rectangle or rhombus has 0 lines of symmetry. If you fold it along any line, the two halves do not match.
common_errors: Saying a parallelogram has 2 lines of symmetry (confusing symmetry with parallel sides)
Not testing by folding or using a mirror, and guessing instead

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading plotted points on a time graph and answering 'what was the value at time X?' questions.
levels.example_task: This graph shows temperature over the day. What was the temperature at 12:00?
levels.example_response: The temperature at 12:00 was 18°C. [Reads from the plotted point]
common_errors: Reading the wrong axis (giving the time when asked for the temperature)
Misreading the scale on the y-axis

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading values between plotted points (interpolation) and describing the overall trend of a time graph.
levels.example_task: The graph shows temperature readings at 10:00 (14°C) and 12:00 (18°C). Estimate the temperature at 11:00.
levels.example_response: About 16°C. The line goes up evenly between 14 and 18, so halfway (11:00) is about 16.
common_errors: Only reading plotted points and not estimating between them
Saying 'I can't tell because there is no data point at 11:00'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Interpreting time graphs to describe trends, calculate changes, and compare different data sets on the same graph.
levels.example_task: Between which two hours did the temperature rise the fastest? How much did it rise in total from 8:00 to 16:00?
levels.example_response: The temperature rose fastest between 10:00 and 12:00 (the line is steepest there — it went up 4°C in 2 hours). Total rise from 8:00 (10°C) to 16:00 (20°C) = 10°C.
common_errors: Identifying the steepest section by looking at the highest point rather than the steepest slope
Computing the total change incorrectly (subtracting from the wrong values)
